executive_summary: Community colleges have struggled to stop their downward trajectory over most of the five years to 2023. When the pandemic caused the national unemployment rate to spike in 2020, many students who would have otherwise enrolled in a community college deferred or delayed their admission. After the labor market's triumphant return in 2021 and 2022, growth in travel and other alternatives fueled a lack of interest in community colleges and higher education. Because of these challenges, industry-wide revenue has been falling at an annualized CAGR of 2.1% over the past five years and is expected to total $63.5 billion in 2023, when revenue will swell by an estimated 0.8%.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Declining Enrollment Has Challenged Community Colleges
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: - Enrollment in community colleges has fallen every year since 2011 except 2021 and was exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic. - Many students deferred or delayed enrollment in 2020, and, while many returned the following year, a large group simply entered the workforce and didn't return to school. - Enrollment dropped over 10.0% in 2020 for two-year public colleges, while nonprofit and for-profit two-year colleges faced lesser drops. - Rising wages have made working a more viable option for many consumers, further pushing down enrollment.

The federal government allocated $12.6 billion to community colleges through the Higher Education Emergency Relief Fund (HEERF) in an effort to help combat losses from lowered enrollment and other pandemic-related challenges. These funds have helped make up for inconsistencies in municipal or state funds, which usually account for over half the industry's revenue but have been unreliable through the pandemic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Community Colleges Expand to New Markets
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Despite declining revenue, demand for certain areas of higher education, job training and skilled professions remains strong. A shortage of nurses and other healthcare professionals has stimulated demand for relevant training in recent years, causing many community colleges to expand their course offerings to include the necessary certification programs. To remedy falling enrollment, institutions like New York's Hudson Valley Community College are partnering with other countries and local faith organizations in an effort to find success with students overseas. Community colleges are also expanding into younger markets by rolling out dual enrollment programs that allow high school students to get started earning college credits as early as 16.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Profit Has Compressed Through the Pandemic
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While many community colleges are nonprofit organizations, for-profit public colleges have struggled with margin compression over the past five years. Falling revenue makes the industry's fixed costs less manageable and translates to declining profit. Utility costs, especially energy expenses, have surged in the aftermath of COVID-19, pushing profit to a historic low.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consistent Government Funding Will Stabilize Revenue
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: - Government funding for community colleges is projected to steadily climb through the end of 2028. - Federal tuition assistance programs make community colleges more affordable for students, boosting revenue from tuition and other student-related fees. - Grants and appropriations directly awarded to industry institutions are critical to the success of community colleges and will help make up for challenges from low admissions and low tuition.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Enrollment Will Finally Return to Growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: - The National Center for Education Statistics predicts that enrollment will return to growth in 2024, marking the end of a decade of nearly constant decline. - This is in part a result of rising demand for highly skilled workers capable of performing difficult tasks in healthcare, STEM and professional services. - Flexibility from innovative courses will boost enrollment by making college more accessible to working consumers.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Online Education is Here to Stay
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: - While many community colleges had already been experimenting with fully online courses and remote learning, the COVID-19 pandemic forced many in-person classes to move exclusively online. - Remote classes enable a single professor to teach more students, cutting wage costs for colleges with appropriate systems in place.

industry_definition: This industry includes public, private nonprofit and for-profit community colleges. These post-secondary educational institutions offer college transfer courses and programs, occupational programs and general educational programs. Community colleges generally confer associate degrees, certificates or diplomas below the baccalaureate level. This industry does not include trade and technical schools (IBISWorld report 61151) or business certification and IT schools (61144).

positive_impact_factors: High and Increasing Industry Assistance Level
High and Steady Barriers To Entry Level

key_trends: Enrollment has consistently declined over the past decade. The National Center for Education Statistics predicts that 2024 will mark a return to growth, though, signaling the end of a period of difficulty for community colleges.

Profit has continued to fall. Falling revenue as a result of declining enrollment has damaged the industry's margins, but heightened government funding through the HEERF has made this compression more manageable.

State and local governments fund community colleges. Federal assistance makes up less than 3.0% of revenue, while state and local governments provide over half. The reliance on long-term funding sources cushions the industry from volatility.
Community colleges must be accredited. In order to receive any federal aid, colleges need to be rigorously reviewed and comply with ADA and Title IX regulations.
Certificates are popular options for students. These programs are quick and cheap, allowing students to enter or return to the workforce sooner rather than later.

Online courses are attracting students. Fully remote classes are allowing colleges to save on wage costs and give students more flexibility in creating their schedules. This has also opened the door for dual enrollment systems that tapping into new, younger markets.

Younger adults make up the bulk of students. High school graduates aged 18 to 21 are nearly half the industry's market, but older adults returning to school are more likely to choose a community college over a four-year university.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This is the fastest-growing market for college careers as high schoolers use remote learning to earn credits for an advanced degree.

products_and_services.product_description: Certificate and nondegree programs can be completed in less than a year and are more focused on employment preparation than continued education.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Liberal Arts and Sciences Associate Degrees
products_and_services.product_description: Liberal arts and sciences programs provide general education across various subjects and are especially attractive to student looking to transfer to four-year universities.

Healthcare profession programs have continued to be in high demand, and nursing is a particularly popular program among students. This segment faces strong competition from four-year universities, though, that offer more rigorous and comprehensive nursing and healthcare programs.

Other associate degree programs include business degrees as well as homeland security, law enforcement, firefighting, computer and information sciences and more. The expanse of degrees covered in this segment make it a large portion of revenue.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Computer and Information Sciences Associate Degrees
products_and_services.product_description: This segment also includes degrees in General Education, which are common for new college students that haven't decided on a major yet but want to explore fields to find one that interest them.

tier_2_suppliers: Computer Peripheral Manufacturing in the US
Municipal Building Construction in the US
Athletic & Sporting Goods Manufacturing in the US
Office Stationery Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Recent high school graduates make up the largest percentage of community college students. High school retention rate marginally increased over the past five years, but rising tuition costs at four-year institutions have bolstered community college enrollment for students who ultimately want to pursue four-year degrees.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Students aged 22 to 29 go back to school
demand_determinants.determinant_description: This market segment is largely composed of individuals returning to college after a hiatus or attending to support a career change.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Students aged 30 and older have settled into careers
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Community colleges tend to have a more balanced age profile than four-year colleges and universities or trade schools. Older adults have settled into careers and don't often return to school, but are more likely to choose a community college when they do.

Students under the age of 18 constitute a relatively large share of total student enrollment in community colleges when compared with traditional four-year colleges and universities. Expansion of dual enrollment programs became a major priority for many high schools and has enabled high schoolers to begin working on a college degree as young as 16.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast currently accounts for one-quarter of the nation's population, and the low concentration through most of the region creates more markets for small community colleges.

The large population in the West makes it the second-largest region for community colleges, as a high population raises the number of college-aged individuals seeking to further their education. The presence of high-earning careers in the area makes consumers more likely to attend a higher education institution as well.

Again, population is a key factor in determining the prevalence of community colleges in a region, so the Plains region naturally doesn't host as many higher education institutions. Population density also affects the industry, and community colleges in concentrated regions like New England are able to service more students per establishment.

regulations_points.regulation_description: In order to qualify for any forms of federal aid, all higher education institutions must be accredited by a nationally recognized accrediting agency. This lengthy process involves a review of the college's curriculums, policies

Community colleges must comply with the Clery Act, which requires them to disclose information about crime on campus. This includes providing annual reports on crime statistics, issuing timely warnings about threats to safety, and having solid emergency response and evacuation procedures in place.

Title IX prohibits discrimination based on sex in educational programs that receive federal financial aid and requires that colleges have policies to address and prevent sexual harassment and assault. Colleges also need to create accessible facilities and provide reasonable accommodations to comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).

barriers_points.barrier_description: It's very expensive to hire and retain the skilled and highly educated faculty needed to teach college courses. More than half of industry revenue goes to wage expenses, though the prevalence of online courses has lessened labor intensity.

basis_points.basis_title: Low prices are a key basis of competition
basis_points.basis_description: Community colleges have to offer low prices. The main benefit of community college over a four-year institution is the cheaper financial burden on the student, and financial aid and scholarship packages sweeten the deal even more.

Colleges compete for both students and faculty. Students have several options to pick from when seeking higher education, so community colleges need to offer competitive wages to bring in educated professors that will in turn make the school attractive to students.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Community colleges are largely funded by municipalities and state governments, so the distribution of these institutions naturally follows regional boundaries.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Majority of students from local area
concentration_points.concentration_description: The overwhelming majority of students at community colleges are from the area, and it's exceedingly rare for a two-year community college to attract students from other states.
Community colleges charge higher tuitions for out-of-state students, and students moving for college are much more likely to move for a four-year
Most community colleges are nonprofit institutions, so there is little incentive to buy out competitors or capture other markets.
Community colleges do open up new branches or satellite locations, but these sites usually still are located in the same municipality the original campus was founded to serve.

The age of the Internet has enabled colleges to find new ways to make up for lost revenue, though, and a popular option is to outsource the educational programs of one department to another school with more faculty or experience in the field.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Community colleges also pay for research expenditures, legal fees, student services, financial aid, accounting services, insurance premiums and building maintenance.
To offset some of these costs, many colleges rent out facilities to third parties for events or conferences when not in use.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: It's very expensive to hire and retain the skilled and highly educated faculty needed to teach college courses. More than half of industry revenue goes to wage expenses, though the prevalence of online courses has lessened labor intensity.

The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry. This creates an environment where the threat of new technologies driving disruption is low.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Community colleges benefit from a wide range of funding sources, which help dampen the impact of declines in one source. State and local governments provide over half the industry's revenue, and the long-term nature of government legislation cushions the industry against volatility.

Community colleges provide education and training for a wide range of students, including those seeking a degree, those seeking to transfer to a four-year institution, and those seeking career training. This broad range of offerings and services means that demand for community college education is relatively inelastic, meaning that it isn't subject to large fluctuations based on changes in economic conditions or other factors.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Certificate and nondegree programs can be completed in less than a year and are more focused on employment preparation than continued education. Students can earn certificates in subjects like accounting and healthcare services, or take courses simply out of personal interest like music or foreign languages.

Liberal arts and sciences programs provide general education across various subjects and are especially attractive to student looking to transfer to four-year universities. Completing General Education (Gen Ed) courses at a lower-cost community college helps students save on earning a bachelor's degree from a more expensive university.

Healthcare profession programs have continued to be in high demand, and nursing is a particularly popular program among students. This segment faces strong competition from four-year universities, though, that offer more rigorous and comprehensive nursing and healthcare programs.

Other associate degree programs include business degrees as well as homeland security, law enforcement, firefighting, computer and information sciences and more. The expanse of degrees covered in this segment make it a large portion of revenue.

FAQs.question: What are the key compliance requirements for community colleges?
FAQs.answer: Community colleges must comply with the Clery Act, which requires disclosing information about campus crime, issuing timely safety warnings, and having emergency response procedures. They also need to comply with Title IX prohibiting sex discrimination, and the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA) for accessible facilities and accommodations.

FAQs.question: How can community colleges leverage industry assistance?
FAQs.answer: Industry-specific associations host networking conferences and provide advice. The American Association of Community Colleges (AACC) plays an advocacy role, representing over 1,000 institutions and nearly 12 million students. The College Board, a nonprofit, offers assistance with admissions, guidance, assessment, and financial aid.

FAQs.question: How can digital marketing channels be used to promote programs and attract students?
FAQs.answer: Utilizing digital platforms allows for targeted advertising, reaching potential students and maximizing enrollment.

FAQs.question: How can strategic partnerships with businesses benefit community colleges?
FAQs.answer: Collaborating with local employers provides practical learning opportunities through internships and demonstrates the value of the institution to potential students and faculty.

FAQs.question: Why do community colleges invest in amenities?
FAQs.answer: The ability to provide students with access to computer facilities, libraries, lecture theaters and other amenities is a significant basis of competition for community colleges.

FAQs.question: How can student support services enhance student engagement and success?
FAQs.answer: Providing comprehensive support services like career counseling and academic advising improves the overall student experience and increases retention rates, positioning colleges for higher future enrollment.

FAQs.question: How can data analytics and learning management systems benefit community colleges?
FAQs.answer: Harnessing data analytics and learning management systems can help identify at-risk students, tailor instructional strategies, provide targeted support to improve outcomes in virtual environments, and enable data-driven decision-making by tracking KPIs like enrollment, student success, and program outcomes.

FAQs.question: How reliant are community colleges on government funding?
FAQs.answer: Government funding is a vital source of income for most community colleges.

FAQs.question: How do community colleges ensure regulatory compliance?
FAQs.answer: Compliance with accreditation standards is essential for maintaining the reputation and credibility of the institution, requiring necessary documentation and reporting to demonstrate program quality and integrity.

FAQs.question: How can financial aid strategies increase accessibility for diverse students?
FAQs.answer: Implementing effective financial aid programs increases accessibility and allows students to pursue education without being burdened by financial constraints.

FAQs.question: How can budget optimization ensure financial sustainability?
FAQs.answer: Efficient budgeting and cost management practices enable the institution to allocate resources strategically and maximize financial stability.

FAQs.question: How do course offerings and admission requirements impact enrollment?
FAQs.answer: Community colleges that offer a wider range of courses are more likely to attract large numbers of students. Admission to community colleges is generally open to all members of the community.

FAQs.question: How can enrollment strategies attract and retain diverse students?
FAQs.answer: Knowing current enrollment helps assess the college's financial health and capacity to repay loans. Optimizing enrollment strategies ensures a stable student base, enhancing loan repayment prospects.

FAQs.question: How can community colleges attract local support and increase enrollment?
FAQs.answer: Community colleges that attract support from local communities are able to increase enrollments and attract greater funding.

FAQs.question: How can changes in unemployment rates impact community college demand?
FAQs.answer: The national unemployment rate affects individuals' decisions regarding education and retraining. Anticipating its impact on community college enrollment helps to proactively plan. Strategies to adapt to enrollment shifts ensure responsiveness to student and labor market needs.

FAQs.question: How does government funding impact financial stability and program continuity?
FAQs.answer: Government funding significantly influences financial stability and resources. Awareness helps to budget and allocate resources for sustaining educational programs.

FAQs.question: What percentage of students come directly from high school?
FAQs.answer: An increase in the number of students graduating from high school directly correlates with an increase in the number of college freshmen. Higher high school retention rates lead to higher community college enrollments.
